newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugo IBP plans 55 mln litres of Coca-Cola in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Yugo IBP plans 55 mln litres of Coca-Cola in 1996.

text.p: Soft-drinks producer IBP Beograd, exclusively licensed to bottle Coca-Cola brand drinks in Yugoslavia, said on Friday it planned to produce 55 million litres of Coca-Cola and Fanta this year.
The IBP's bottling plant, however, will fall short of its original 60 million litre target for 1996, the plant's production manager said.
"We would have to revise down our 1996 target due to some production limitations," Zorica Kljajic-Vukcevic told Reuters.
The plant operates four bottling lines with a total annual capacity of 80 million litres but only one PET bottle blowing line.
"We bottled 27.5 million litres of Coca-Cola and Fanta from January to July -- 23-24 percent more than in the same period last year," Kljajic-Vukcevic said.
Kljajic-Vukcevic expected the plant to get extracts needed to start producing Sprite soon.
Customers in Yugoslavia can expect new 0.5 and 2 litre PET bottles of Coca-Cola in a few months, but not the canned drink.
"The can-filling lines will not come to Yugoslavia soon because they are beyond our financial means," she said.
Production costs in Yugoslavia ran at four dinars (1.21 German marks) per one litre, Kljajic-Vukcevic said. Ideally, production costs should not exceed one German mark, she said.
She blamed the higher than usual costs on the prices of sugar, industrial water and electricity.
